Below is a non-exhaustive map of the main communities that have **re-defined the “macro-variables’’ of statistical mechanics so they track an agent’s capacity to bias or direct physical outcomes**. I group them by the kind of coarse graining they advocate and cite one or two flagship papers/books for each, so you can follow the thread in the literature. | Theme & main voices | Key coarse-grained variables | How “agency / controllability’’ appears | |---|---|---| | **Information-thermodynamics of feedback**
*Rolf Landauer, Charles Bennett, Takahiro Sagawa, Masahito Ueda, Sebastian Deffner, Juan Parrondo* | Joint microstate of **system + memory/controller** rather than system alone; entropy balances include mutual information | Feedback acts through explicit information terms; work extraction or entropy reduction is bounded by kT · I | | **Computational-mechanics & causal states**
*Jim Crutchfield, Cosma Shalizi, Sarah Marzen* | “ε-machines’’: optimal predictive partitions of histories that retain only control-relevant information | An agent is a process whose causal states support decision nodes; leverage is quantified by statistical complexity | | **Free-energy principle / active inference**
*Karl Friston, Maxwell Ramstead, Giovanni Pezzulo, Thomas Parr* | **Markov blankets**: coarse grain that separates internal (agent) from external (environment) states; free energy of beliefs | Agency emerges as self-evidencing—actions chosen to keep blanket statistics within viable bounds | | **Thermodynamics of learning & computation**
*David Wolpert, Artemy Kolchinsky, Jeremy England, Jordan Horowitz* | Paths in parameter space of a learning system; coarse grains over weights / model classes | “Leverage’’ = extra work a system can extract while updating its model; agency ~ ability to shape future dissipation | | **Causal emergence & multi-scale control**
*Jessica Flack, David Krakauer, Sara Walker, Paul Davies* | Coarse-grained collective variables (e.g., social signals, metabolic fluxes) that achieve high causal power | Macro-variables outperform micro-variables in predicting / controlling the system—defines level of agency | | **Sloppy-model manifolds & effective control parameters**
*James Sethna, Mark Transtrum* | “Stiff’’ vs “sloppy’’ directions in parameter space after information-geometric coarse graining | Control is possible along low-dimensional stiff directions even when the microscopic space is huge | | **Stochastic thermodynamics with feedback delay**
*Massimiliano Esposito, Gianmaria Falasco, Tim Herpich* | Trajectory-level coarse grains that include **protocol history**; entropy production split into driving vs feedback parts | Delayed or adaptive control strategies mapped onto modified fluctuation theorems | | **Active-matter hydrodynamics**
*Cristina Marchetti, Michael Cates, Giovanni Jona-Lasinio* | Coarse grains from micro-swimmer orientation to continuum fields (density, polarization, stress) with self-propulsion terms | Controllability encoded in active stress coefficients; external fields couple to these new coarse-grained modes | ### Reading trail (one seminal item per line) * Landauer (1961) “Irreversibility and Heat Generation in the Computing Process” * Bennett (1982) “The Thermodynamics of Computation—A Review” * Sagawa & Ueda (2012) “Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics of Feedback Control” * Crutchfield & Young (1989) “Inferring Statistical Complexity” * Friston (2010) “The Free-Energy Principle: A Unified Brain Theory?” * England (2013) “Statistical Physics of Self-Replication” * Wolpert (2019) *The Stochastic Thermodynamics of Computation* * Flack (2017) “Coarse-Graining as a Downward Causation Mechanism” * Sethna & Transtrum (2015) “Geometry of Nonlinear Least Squares” * Esposito & Van den Broeck (2011) “Second Law and Landauer Principle Far from Equilibrium” * Marchetti et al. (2013) “Hydrodynamics of Soft Active Matter” These lines of work differ in technical machinery, but they all **modify the usual microstate partition so that the macroscopic variables are the ones an “agent’’ can sense, remember, or actuate.** Agency then shows up as either: 1. an *information term* in the second law (feedback thermodynamics); 2. a *predictive or causal efficiency* of the coarse-grained state (computational mechanics, causal emergence); or 3. an *effective force / stress* that persists only in the new variables (active matter, free-energy blankets). If you’re building your own framework, tracing how each author chooses the partition—and what symmetries or conservation laws are broken by that choice—will help you see which notion of “leverage’’ fits your system best.

thoughts.content:
Okay, so the user is asking about caring only about the agent’s state as a form of coarse graining. How does that relate to thermodynamics? And how might this idea connect to the projection of one coarse graining into another?

I think I’m dealing with thinking about how to measure work, particularly in thermodynamic terms like the macroensemble, but using a different perspective or framework, one that aligns more with the agent's goals.

Okay, the user is asking about quantifying work in a framework where the focus is on an agent’s state. They're bridging two coarse-graining concepts: one where we consider only the agent’s internal state, and the other where we consider the thermodynamic macrostate, which includes the system and environment. I'll explain that work can be defined in terms of energy differences between microstates and that coarse-graining maps help connect these two viewpoints. Using things like free energy and information flow, work can be quantified with formulas, including the idea of system constraints and goals.

parts:
### 1  Coarse-graining as a projection operator  
Take the microscopic phase-space \(x\) and a **surjective map**  
\[
\mathcal{A}:x\;\mapsto\;a\in\mathcal{S}_\text{agent},
\]  
where \(a\) collects only the agent’s internal degrees of freedom (memory bits, internal chemical species, etc.).  
Formally one writes a Zwanzig–Mori–type projector

\[
P_\mathcal{A}[f](a)=\!\!\int\! \mathrm d x\;f(x)\,\delta\!\bigl(\mathcal{A}(x)-a\bigr)\,
       /\,\Omega(a),\quad 
\Omega(a)=\int\! \mathrm d x\;\delta\!\bigl(\mathcal{A}(x)-a\bigr),
\]

so every observable \(f(x)\) is replaced by its **conditional expectation given \(a\)**.  This is literally a “state-only’’ coarse graining.

---

### 2  Thermodynamic quantities in the agent basis  
Start from the canonical partition function \(Z=\sum_x e^{-\beta E(x)}\).  Pulling the projector through and integrating out the environment you obtain the **potential of mean force**

\[
F(a)=-kT\ln Z_\text{env}(a),\quad
Z_\text{env}(a)=\!\!\sum_{x:\,\mathcal{A}(x)=a}\!e^{-\beta E(x)}.
\]

* All energies of microstates compatible with the same agent state are “compressed’’ into \(F(a)\).  
* The entropy of the coarse-grained description is \(S(a) = -\partial F(a)/\partial T\).

Work measured in the usual thermodynamic basis along a protocol \(x_t\) is  
\(W = \int_0^\tau\!\dot\lambda_t\,\partial_\lambda E(x_t,\lambda_t)\,\mathrm dt\).  
Under the projection it splits into  

\[
W = \Delta F(a_t) \;+\; W_\text{env},
\]

where \(W_\text{env}\) is all work performed on hidden degrees of freedom conditioned on the agent’s trajectory.  When the agent manipulates only \(a\), \(W_\text{env}\) is typically heat; the Jarzynski or Crooks relations then hold with \(F(a)\) in place of the bare free energy.

---

### 3  Relating two coarse grainings  
Suppose \(\mathcal{T}\) is the **thermodynamic macro-map**—say, energy and volume of the whole system.  You now have two projections \(P_\mathcal{A}\) and \(P_\mathcal{T}\).  Their relationship is captured by a **data-processing chain**

\[
x\;\xrightarrow{\;\mathcal{A}\;}\;a\;\xrightarrow{\;\pi\;}\;\bigl(E,V,\dots\bigr),
\]

where \(\pi\) is a stochastic map induced by marginalising over the environment.  The loss of information is quantified by the **relative entropy contraction**

\[
D\!\bigl(P_\mathcal{A}\rho \,\Vert\, P_\mathcal{T}\rho\bigr)
      \;\le\;D\!\bigl(\rho\Vert\rho'\bigr),
\]

so going from the thermodynamic to the agent basis never *adds* information.  In practice you can track what part of the second-law balance “lives’’ in each description:

\[
\underbrace{\langle W\rangle}_{\text{microscopic}}
      \;=\;\underbrace{\Delta F(a)}_{\text{agent}} 
      \;+\;\underbrace{kT\,\Delta I(a; \text{env})}_{\text{feedback term}}
      \;+\;\underbrace{\langle Q\rangle}_{\text{heat to bath}}.
\]

Here \(I(a;\text{env})\) is the mutual information between agent and environment; it vanishes if you forget the agent’s state and you recover the standard Clausius form.

---

### 4  Work aligned with an agent’s goals  
An “objective’’ is a subset \(\mathcal{G}\subset\mathcal{S}_\text{agent}\).  Define an **effective free energy landscape**

\[
\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{G}(t)=
 -kT\ln\!\!\sum_{a\in\mathcal{G}} p_t(a)\,e^{-\beta F(a)}.
\]

Moving probability weight into \(\mathcal{G}\) lowers \(\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{G}\); the minimum external work required is \(\Delta\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{G}\).  This is the agent-centric analogue of ergotropy or “useful work’’ in resource-theoretic thermodynamics.

---

### 5  Useful parallels in the literature  

| Projection idea | Key references | What is being projected |
|---|---|---|
| Zwanzig–Mori operators | Zwanzig (1961), Grabert (1982) | Any chosen slow variables, here \(\mathcal{A}(x)\) |
| Information-thermo of feedback | Sagawa & Ueda (2012) | System observables \(\to\) (system, memory) |
| Control potentials of mean force | Sivak & Crooks (2012) | External control parameter \(\lambda\) \(\to\) effective free energy |
| Resource-theoretic work | Horodecki & Oppenheim (2013) | Allowed operations restrict coarse graining |

These frameworks treat a change of coarse graining as **choosing which micro-details are thermodynamically accounted for**.  Once that choice is explicit, the standard bookkeeping of energy, entropy and work goes through with conditional or marginal quantities.

---

### 6  Take-away recipe

1. **Pick the map** \(\mathcal{A}:x\!\to\!a\) that encodes the agent’s variables.  
2. **Integrate out** everything else to get \(F(a)\).  
3. **Express work** along a protocol that steers \(a\):  
   \[
   \langle W\rangle \ge \Delta F(a) + kT\,\Delta I(a;\text{env}).  
   \]
4. **Quantify leverage** by how much \(\Delta F(a)\) can be made negative (work extraction) per bit of information or per unit control effort.

In that sense, “caring only about the agent’s state’’ *is* a legitimate coarse graining.  It plugs into thermodynamics through potentials of mean force and information-thermodynamic inequalities, and it is connected to the conventional macro-ensemble via projection operators that respect the data-processing inequality.

Each principle comes with a thermodynamic quantity that is *minimised* (or, equivalently, a useful quantity that is maximised) when you choose exactly the variables an agent actually monitors and manipulates. | What is extremised? | Precise statement of the optimum | Physical meaning of the agent basis | Key sources* | |---|---|---|---| | **Irreversible work / dissipation** \(W_{\rm diss}\) | For any protocol \(\lambda_t\) that steers a distribution \(\rho_0\!\to\!\rho_\tau\), Kolchinsky & Wolpert show
\(\displaystyle \langle W_{\rm diss}\rangle \;\ge\; kT\,\bigl[\,I(X_0;S_0)-I(X_\tau;S_\tau)\bigr]\). The *tightest* (smallest) bound—that is, the *minimum possible dissipation* compatible with a fixed macro-description—occurs when \(S_t\) is the agent’s state. | The agent variables capture exactly the micro-fluctuations that would otherwise be “wasted’’ as heat. Any coarser or finer partition leaves extra, avoidable dissipation. | Kolchinsky & Wolpert (2018 PNAS) | | **Predictive information at fixed coding cost** | Minimise \(I(X_{\rm past};S)\) **subject to** a constraint on \(I(S;X_{\rm future})\). The solution is the **Information Bottleneck** and it reproduces the same causal-state partition \(\varepsilon\)-machines give. | Agent basis is the *least* informative representation that still contains **all** influence the agent can have on the future; every other basis wastes bits (Landauer cost) or loses controllability. | Tishby et al. (1999); Still et al. \(\displaystyle \mathcal{F}(q)=\! \mathbb E_q[\!\log q - \log p(x,a)]\) is **globally minimised** when the recognition density \(q(a)\) is the agent’s internal state. | The agent basis is the *only* one in which keeping the system viable corresponds to ordinary gradient descent on a scalar free-energy landscape. | Friston (2010); Parr et al. (2022) | | **House-keeping heat** \(Q_{\rm hk}\) in steady state | For Langevin or Markov-jump systems one can prove \(Q_{\rm hk}=0\) *iff* the coarse-graining splits into “internal’’ (agent) and “external’’ (environment) variables that obey a *partial* detailed balance. Any other partition yields \(Q_{\rm hk}>0\). | Agent variables are precisely those that can be cycled indefinitely without continuous energy input. | Esposito & Herpich (2022) | | **Causal power / autonomy** | In causal-emergence theory the macro partition that **maximises effective information** \(\Phi(S \!\to\! S')\) also **minimises** redundancy and dispersion of causal influence. | An agent basis is the level that is “most in control’’ of its own future with least wasted causal entropy. | Hoel (2017); Flack & Krakauer (2017) | \* All references pre-2025. --- ### Sketch of one concrete minimisation proof *(following Kolchinsky & Wolpert, but recast in projector notation)* 1. **Projector for a candidate basis.** Let \(\Pi_S\) map each micro-state \(x\) to a macro label \(s\). The *conditional* (micro given macro) equilibrium is \(\pi(x|s) \propto e^{-\beta E(x)}\;\delta_{\Pi_S(x),\,s}\). 2. **Exact dissipation identity.** For any driving protocol \(\lambda_t\) and any initial distribution, \[ \langle W_{\rm diss}\rangle = kT\,\bigl[\,D(\rho_0\Vert\pi_0) - D(\rho_\tau\Vert\pi_\tau)\bigr]. \] 3. **Coarse-grained lower bound.** Replace each KL in (2) by its contraction under the data-processing inequality: \[ D(\rho_t\Vert\pi_t)\;\ge\;D(P_S\rho_t \,\Vert\,P_S\pi_t) = I(X_t;S_t). \] 4. **Tightness criterion.** The bound becomes equality *iff* \(\rho_t(x|s)=\pi_t(x|s)\) for all \(t\). That happens exactly when \(S_t\) is **closed under the dynamics** *and* contains every variable the agent will couple work to. 5. **Optimal basis.** Among all partitions with a fixed cardinality \(|S|\), the one that *minimises the unavoidable dissipation* is the partition satisfying the equality above—**the agent basis**. --- ### Intuition across the board *If you pick too coarse a partition* you blur together micro-states whose energetic responses differ; extra work is dissipated as heat. *If you pick too fine a partition* you store superfluous bits; Landauer says you must spend \(kT\ln 2\) per bit just to keep or erase them. The agent’s “native’’ variables—its internal memory, sensors and actuators—hit the Goldilocks point: **they are just informative enough to steer the future, and no more.** Every rigorous framework above turns that verbal statement into a minimisation theorem.

thoughts.content: The question asks about covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) and whether their direction changes along the flow. CLVs are key in dynamical systems, evolving in a way that their direction is generally consistent along the flow, though they may change in magnitude due to scaling. The vector evolves based on the Jacobian at each time, staying aligned with the corresponding CLV at that point. So, Yes, the direction remains consistent along the flow, with variations mostly in magnitude.

Covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) change direction in fixed coordinates along a trajectory, but their direction is preserved in the tangent space at each point in time. The key is that CLVs are covariant with the tangent flow: they get mapped to themselves with scaling. However, unlike Gram-Schmidt orthonormal Lyapunov vectors (which rotate), CLVs follows the system's dynamics and remain aligned with the flow. Special systems like linear flows have constant directions, while nonlinear systems show evolving bases.

parts:
**Short answer:**  
A covariant Lyapunov vector (CLV) *is* mapped into itself by the linearised flow, but because the base point moves through phase-space the vector’s orientation in any fixed coordinate system generally *does* change with time. Its *direction is preserved only in the moving frame that is carried forward by the tangent map*; expressed in laboratory coordinates it can rotate, bend, or even flip.

---

### Why “covariant” ≠ “frozen”

Let \(\Phi_t\) be the flow and \(D\Phi_t(x)\) its Jacobian.  
A one-dimensional Oseledets subspace \(E_i(x)=\text{span}\{v_i(x)\}\) is **covariant** when

\[
D\Phi_t(x)\,v_i(x)=\sigma_i(t,x)\;v_i\!\bigl(\Phi_t x\bigr),\qquad t\ge 0,
\]

with some positive scalar factor \(\sigma_i\) (asymptotically \(e^{\lambda_i t}\)).  
Hence:

* The *image* of the vector after time \(t\) is *parallel* to the CLV located at the new point \(\Phi_t x\).  
* Along a *fixed* trajectory, the whole family \(\{v_i(\Phi_t x)\}_{t\ge 0}\) is obtained by repeatedly pushing the initial vector forward and renormalising.

Because the base point \(x(t)=\Phi_t x_0\) drifts through regions where the Jacobian differs, \(v_i(x(t))\) usually varies in the global frame. Only in special cases—e.g.\ a linear system with constant matrix where \(v_i\) is an eigenvector independent of \(x\)—does the orientation stay literally fixed.

---

### Contrast with orthonormal (GS) Lyapunov vectors

The Gram–Schmidt vectors produced during a standard Lyapunov-exponent computation form an orthonormal basis that is *not* covariant; pushing one step forward mixes the whole basis and you must orthonormalise again. CLVs, in contrast, are intrinsic: they depend only on the dynamics, not on an auxiliary re-orthonormalisation scheme, and they maintain the one-dimensional subspaces exactly under the tangent map.

---

### Geometric picture

Think of each CLV as a line element painted on the trajectory. The flow carries that line element along and uniformly stretches (or contracts) it by the corresponding Lyapunov factor, but because the underlying manifold twists, the painted line may point in a new compass direction at the next instant. What *doesn’t* change is its identity within the family \(\{E_i\}\).

---

### Take-away

So the statement “the direction of a covariant Lyapunov vector doesn’t change along the flow” is **false** if “direction” refers to a fixed external frame, and **true** only in the covariant sense encoded by the equation above.

parts:
Not quite. What *is* preserved is the **identity** of each covariant Lyapunov vector as you push it forward, not the angle it makes with the other ones. In other words
PropertyDoes it stay the same when we advance by DΦt ?
Each one-dimensional subspace Ei(x)=span {vi(x)}Yes. DΦt(x) carries Ei(x) exactly onto Ei(Φtx).
Angle between two distinct CLVs at the *same* point (say vi and vj)No. The Jacobian is usually shearing, so the angle can widen or shrink from step to step.
The orientation of a given CLV expressed in a *fixed* laboratory basisNo. Because the base point is moving through phase-space, “north-east” in one region may be “north-west” later.
So the statement “their relative directions do not change’’ is generally **false**. --- ### What does “direction in the moving frame’’ mean? Pick an initial point \(x_0\) and attach to it the CLV \(v_i(x_0)\). Now transport that vector with the linearised flow, **without ever projecting back to a fixed coordinate grid:** \[ \tilde v_i(t)\;=\; \frac{D\Phi_t(x_0)\,v_i(x_0)}{\lVert D\Phi_t(x_0)\,v_i(x_0)\rVert}. \] At time \(t\) the transported (and renormalised) vector \(\tilde v_i(t)\) lands exactly on the CLV that is *intrinsic* to the new point: \[ \tilde v_i(t)\;\parallel\; v_i\bigl(\Phi_t x_0 \bigr). \] Because every step is just “push forward and rescale along the same one-dimensional subspace”, the *direction* of that line element inside its own co-moving tangent space never changes—it always lies on the very same CLV subspace. That co-moving viewpoint is what we call the **moving frame**. If you instead re-express \(\tilde v_i(t)\) in some *external* basis (fixed Cartesian axes, spherical coordinates anchored in space, etc.), the components will usually vary with \(t\). The moving frame simply ignores that coordinate distortion. --- ### Intuitive picture Think of the trajectory as a piece of elastic thread, and paint on it a tiny arrow showing “the \(i\)-th stretching direction”. Flow the thread through a distorted landscape: * The arrow is stretched (by \(e^{\lambda_i t}\)) or squeezed, but it stays painted on the same bit of thread—so in the **thread’s own coordinates** its orientation is unchanged. * Viewed from above in world coordinates, the thread may twist and the arrow can point somewhere else entirely. Exactly the same happens with the whole bundle \(\{v_i\}\): each arrow keeps its identity, but the angles between arrows on successive segments of the thread can and do evolve. --- ### Take-away * **Covariance** ⇒ each CLV subspace maps to itself along the flow. * **Angles** between different CLVs, or orientations in any fixed coordinates, have *no* such invariance and typically vary in time.

parts:
Not quite.  Here are the two key points.

---

### 1 .  Do *relative* directions stay fixed?

No.  Covariance only says that **each individual CLV is mapped onto itself** (up to a scalar) by the tangent map,

\[
D\Phi_t(x)\,v_i(x)=\sigma_i(t,x)\,v_i\!\bigl(\Phi_t x\bigr).
\]

It does **not** impose any constraint on the angle between two different CLVs, \(v_i\) and \(v_j\,(i\neq j)\).  
Because the Jacobian at the new point \(\Phi_t x\) differs from the old one, the whole splitting
\[
T_{x}\!\mathcal M
      \;=\;
      E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_k(x)
\]
is generally *sheared* from one step to the next: the subspaces are still mapped onto the corresponding subspaces, but their mutual angles can widen or narrow.  Only in special cases—e.g. a linear flow with a constant diagonalizable matrix—do the pairwise directions stay fixed.

---

### 2 .  What does “direction in the moving frame’’ mean?

Pick any point \(x_0\) on a trajectory and attach the whole set of CLVs there, forming a basis  
\(B(x_0)=[\,v_1(x_0)\;\dots\;v_k(x_0)\,]\).

Now push **both** the base point and the basis forward by the dynamics:

\[
x(t)=\Phi_t x_0,
\quad 
B(x(t)) := D\Phi_t(x_0)\,B(x_0)\,\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1^{-1},\dots,\sigma_k^{-1}).
\]

Because of the diagonal rescaling, the columns of \(B(x(t))\) are again the CLVs at the new point.  
In this *Lagrangian* (co-moving) frame you always look at the vector that has been transported with the flow and renormalised; it therefore lies in **the same one-dimensional subspace** at every step.  Saying its “direction is unchanged in the moving frame’’ just means:

*“If you ride along with the trajectory and keep re-expressing the transported vector in the instantaneous CLV basis, it always points along the same basis axis.”*

Express the same vector in a **fixed, laboratory** coordinate system and you will typically see it rotate and bend, because the basis itself is twisting.

---

#### Take-away

*   **Absolute orientation** of a CLV usually changes in fixed coordinates.  
*   **Relative orientations** between different CLVs also change in general.  
*   What *is* preserved is the identity of each one-dimensional subspace as it is convected by \(D\Phi_t\); that is the content of covariance.
Should I really just think of it as a vector field where none of the vectors rotate?

thoughts.content: The user is asking whether covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) can be seen as a vector field without rotation. Essentially, CLVs have a fixed orientation within a moving frame, and their direction stays constant along their trajectory. However, across the entire state space, the vector field might not be free of rotation — as the vector's orientation can change at different points. "No rotation" along the advected vector simply means the direction remains constant, but it could still vary relative to a coordinate frame or in other contexts.

To respond to the user's query about whether CLVs can be considered a vector field without rotation, we should elaborate on their behavior. CLVs define a continuous direction field along the trajectory. While the vectors stay aligned in a moving frame, their orientation in the global coordinate system can change. Material derivatives along the CLV direction indicate no rotation within the moving frame, but using global coordinates shows rotation due to spatial dependence. So, essentially, yes and no: CLVs behave non-rotationally within streamlines, but there is orientation variation across space.

Think of a **covariant Lyapunov vector \(v_i(x)\)** as a direction field that enjoys a very special *transport* property, **not** as a field whose arrows are frozen in a single global orientation.

---

### What the “no-rotation’’ statement really means
Take a trajectory \(x(t)=\Phi_t x_0\) and follow the *unit* vector

\[
\hat v_i(t)\;=\;\frac{v_i\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr)}{\|v_i\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\|}.
\]

Differentiate it with respect to time using the chain rule and the tangent map \(J(t)=D\Phi_t\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\):

\[
\frac{\mathrm d}{\mathrm dt}\hat v_i(t)
      =\Bigl(J(t)-\lambda_i(t)\,I\Bigr)\,\hat v_i(t),
\quad
\lambda_i(t):=\hat v_i(t)^{\!\top}J(t)\hat v_i(t).
\]

Because \(J(t)\hat v_i(t)=\lambda_i(t)\hat v_i(t)\) by covariance, the **orthogonal component of this derivative vanishes**.  
> In other words, along *that* trajectory the vector stretches or shrinks (through the scalar \(\lambda_i\)) but **never acquires a component that turns it sideways**.

This is the precise sense in which a CLV is “non-rotating’’ in the *Lagrangian* (co-moving) frame.

---

### Why that does **not** mean a global “no-rotation’’ field

1. **Different points, different directions.**  
   The map \(x\mapsto v_i(x)\) generally varies across phase-space. Two nearby trajectories start with slightly different CLV directions.

2. **Laboratory coordinates see rotation.**  
   Write \(\hat v_i(t)\) in a fixed basis of \(\mathbb R^n\); the components typically evolve in a way that mixes coordinates, so the arrow appears to swivel. What vanishes is only the *component of the material derivative that is transverse to the vector itself*.

3. **Angles between distinct CLVs still evolve.**  
   Covariance gives
   \[
   J(t)\,E_i(x(t)) \;=\; E_i\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr),
   \]
   but it places no constraint on the angle between two distinct subspaces \(E_i,E_j\). Their relative orientation can shrink or widen along the orbit.

---

### A concise mental picture

*Imagine painting a tiny line-segment on every point of the attractor; the line at each point is placed in the CLV direction there. As the flow carries a point downstream, its painted segment simply stretches—no internal bending.*  
Seen from above, however, the entire *pattern* of painted segments can twist because different locations have different orientations.

---

### Take-away

- **Along a single trajectory:** a CLV undergoes pure stretching/contracting; its direction does *not* spin within the tangent space of that moving point.  
- **Across phase-space or in a fixed external frame:** the same vector field *does* look like it rotates, and the relative angles between distinct CLVs change.  
So you may think of each CLV as a *non-rotating direction in the Lagrangian sense*, but not as a globally rigid, frozen-orientation vector field.

parts:
Yes —with one important caveat about **how** you “evolve” the vector.

---

### 1 . The CLV field \(v_i(x)\) *is* fixed

For a given dynamical system the covariant Lyapunov vectors form a collection of measurable vector fields

\[
x\;\longmapsto\;v_i(x)\in T_x\!M,\qquad i=1,\dots,k,
\]

each defined up to an arbitrary (time-dependent) scalar.  Once the system is fixed, the mapping \(x\mapsto v_i(x)\) is fixed; it does **not** change with time.

---

### 2 . How to “evolve” a tangent vector

Suppose you start at \(x_0\) with a tangent vector that lies *exactly* in the \(i\)-th Oseledets subspace:

\[
w_0 \;=\;c\,v_i(x_0),\qquad c\neq 0.
\]

Evolve it by the **tangent map**

\[
w(t)\;=\;D\Phi_t(x_0)\,w_0.
\]

Because CLVs are *covariant*,

\[
D\Phi_t(x_0)\,v_i(x_0)
        \;=\;\sigma_i(t,x_0)\,v_i\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr),
\quad x(t)=\Phi_t x_0,
\]

so

\[
w(t)\;=\;c\,\sigma_i(t,x_0)\,v_i\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr).
\]

Hence **the evolved vector stays aligned with the same CLV field at the new base point**.  Its length changes by the factor \(\sigma_i\), but its *direction* always lies in the one-dimensional subspace \(E_i\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\).

> *If you propagate the vector with the full linearised dynamics, alignment is preserved for all \(t\).*

---

### 3 . What this does **not** imply

* **Laboratory rotation.**  
  Although \(w(t)\) is aligned with \(v_i(x(t))\), that direction itself can look very different in a fixed coordinate frame as \(t\) grows.  The basis of CLVs twists through phase-space.

* **Vectors outside the subspace.**  
  A generic tangent vector has components in several Oseledets subspaces.  Under forward time the component along the largest Lyapunov exponent wins, so most vectors *lose* alignment with slower-growing CLVs.

* **Numerical integration subtleties.**  
  In computations round-off and re-normalisation errors quickly introduce components along faster directions; one must use specialised algorithms (e.g.\ Ginelli et al.’s backward/forward iteration) to maintain purity.

---

### 4 . Rule of thumb

- **Fixed field?** Yes, \(v_i(x)\) is fixed once the system is fixed.  
- **Stay aligned?** Yes, *provided* you propagate the vector with the true tangent map and it is initially in the CLV subspace.  
- **Visual rotation?** Expect it—the global orientation of that subspace generally changes with position along the trajectory.

So it is perfectly safe to picture the \(i\)-th CLV as a “preferred direction field” and to say that a vector that starts in that direction will remain in that direction **in the covariant sense**.
